displayed_text: Patient: Mm. Doctor: It really is are there new things about you that are going in the wrong direction and yet after radiation, it seems like things are in a better direction at least in the last month in terms of your pain. Patient: Oh yes, absolutely. Doctor: We’ve got a CAT scan that I don’t have access to, but sort of what does that show? And with you know new belly films you know to sort of say what’s going on in your liver, you know so Dr. G___ and I can talk about that, sort of when, what images we need, to say okay his PSA is higher and on scan we see more cancer. And you know some of what we’re really talking about is what do we do if we tell you that. Does that bring up questions? Patient: In other words where do we go from here? Doctor: What is your understanding or what Dr. G__ talked about. Patient: Nothing really new that I remember that he thought you know with the ARB7, is that it? Doctor: V as in Victor. Patient: Oh ARV7 and thought that you know there were some possibilities there. The liver pathology at Hospital B he wasn’t real keen on and so he had the samples sent up here. Doctor: And they confirmed that it’s prostate cancer. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah, rather than liver cancer, yes, and that’s kind of where we stand. Family Member: The only difference is Dr G___ was emphatic about having T__ call him after he had visited with you because he would like to know what you had to say.

Patient: No. What I- you’re looking if I can get on it. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: You’re looking at clinical trials, I guess. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I see. So, yeah, so that one is an option for you especially now that the PSA is going up slightly. If you want to do it, that is an option. Patient: What is it? Doctor: Okay. So what it is, is it’s a radiation, a type of radiation that you would get, but it’s tagged to something called PSMA. Family Member: Okay. With what? Doctor: P-S-M-A. Family Member: Oh. P-S-M-A. Doctor: Which is, uh, antigen that a lot of the prostate cancers produce. So what it- what that treatment does, is it attaches to that antigen on the cancer cells and releases the radiation right where the cancer is at. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That is the idea behind it. For that, though, first, what we have to do is make sure that your cancer is actually expressing that antigen.

Patient: Well, I mean (chuckles) Doctor: No, no, I think the hair loss is all pretty much even after one or two, so after we stop the hair grows back. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So, so, that does happen. The other thing to watch for is if there’s tingling or numbness, okay, typically in the fingertips and the toes. If that is happening, I will, you know we may have to make adjustments to the dose. What happens is we start everyone on one standard dose and then dial down, depending on how they’re tolerated. Okay, so, so I think like I told you, the first course pretty much is important because both you and I will find out how you’re going to tolerate. Patient: Right, well my my feet, you know even like right now, they’re a little tingly. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I - you know from sitting in the car for an hour coming up here and that’s - Doctor: Yeah, and the cold right now - Patient: And the cold and sitting - Doctor: And the other thing is as you lose your hair, since we’re doing this right in the middle of winter, you have to protect your head. Family Member: Yeah. Yes. Doctor: Because that’s a sudden change that your body in this cold will really have a tough time getting used to. Yes. Family Member: I had a question about if it does cause nausea (pause)

Healthcare Professional: So Doctor: Oh yeah so now did you actually throw up after the chemo last time? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: How often? How many days? Patient: Two, three days after I had one at home Doctor: Mhmm. Patient: then I had the heat flashes Doctor: Mhmm. Patient: and I still have them every now and then. Doctor: Mhmm. Oh okay so that’s… Patient: And then (pause) Doctor: Okay. No because I was looking into let me just see if we have to increase his uh… Are you driving back home on your own? Patient: No. My mom she’s…

Doctor: So, they’ve, they’ve tested it in Europe in a, in a weird way. So in Europe, the doctors there are allowed to, if they think something could work, they’re allowed to just give it to people. They don’t need FDA kind of approval. Doctor: They don’t need, uh, even data showing that it proves survival. It’s sort of, if, if the doctor feels it could be beneficial, they’re allowed to use it. So they’re not allowed to sell it. They not allowed to make money. So what they’ve been doing is based on using the same material to image prostate cancer. So we give this material with a little bit of radiation on it and it looks really good. We could see spots that we maybe didn’t see before. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The idea was, well, if we can swap out the little bit of radiation and put a lot of radiation, maybe we could treat cancer. So they’ve been treating people kind of on an individual basis. Somebody calls up, shows up, you give it to them. They haven’t said, let’s take a hundred guys with this, you know, kind of like a trial. So they’ve been reporting look how good Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So in the U.S., we kind of have to go down more organized, you know, step-wise fashion. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And for reasons that are complicated related to business and how, you know, how these things happen. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So far, until recently, this hasn’t been in the right hands, I think, to make a drug out of it. Recently, there’s been a lot of interest and a very large company bought the rights to it, and I think they’re going to do it correctly. But it’s been a slow moving thing to get started. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, and some of the complexity relates to, to, uh, how the drug’s supplied. Anyway, so that, that is a radioactive thing that’s coming. The radium, we could do that as just a standard treatment, not even part of a trial. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: No. Doctor: No. Patient: Did you, did you see that Harvard study? Family Member: Okay Patient: I know, I know you are busy, but there was a Harvard study done by the African American study department. I forget his name, C__ something, and they, they took eight very, very prominent African American’s, Oprah, uh, uh, uh who’s the great arranger? Anyway. Ada, Quincy Jones. Doctor: Okay. Patient: All of whom. All of whom. All eight, including the, the black guy who did this study from Harvard, were convinced that they had Native American, uh, genes. None. (Laughs) Doctor: Well, you know, I, I did this myself. Ancest--I did Ancestry. Patient: Yeah. I might do that. Doctor: And, uh, I don’t know what they. I don’t know enough about what they use as a marker to say you’re --- Patient: Yeah, x-y-or z. Doctor: I want to say, I think Native American, there’s certain mutations that might come up that are only in Native American population. So, anyway, my, my story was my, my name is D_. My, there’s a town in England called D_. I had done my genealogy back to eighteen twenty. Until, you know, my --- two generations ago came to America, multiple generations lived in England. Patient: Do you know that for sure?

Family Member: Mmmmm. Doctor: Umm, but. Patient: How long then is, I know the infusion is like half an hour or something? Healthcare Professional: It’s an hour. Patient: It’s an hour. Okay. Then, how long before I get released? Doctor: Uh, the first time, they watch it for a half hour or so just to make sure you don’t have an allergic reaction. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, I, I say plan for three hours, but you know, if we do the Tuesday visit and clear you, then your other visits it can be the shorter end of things because they know you, they expected you, they’ve cleared you. Patient: Yeah, we’ll get into the pattern and we’ll just - Okay. Doctor: But, we’re not using, uh, uh a port. You know, we’re just going to use your regular vein. So, that would be something else that if your veins are too tough to get, uh, something like that. Patient: I’ll tell you that the phlebotomist that did it today was probably the least painful stick I’ve ever had. Doctor: Do you have any other questions?

Patient: Okay do you think… Doctor: Because we’ll really have exhausted that Xtandi is not working definitely before we decide to switch to Lynparza at that point. Patient: How soon will you know? I mean the… Family Member: With the BET. Doctor: With the BET? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m thinking four to six weeks will give us at least an inkling if it’s doing something. Even if it’s stabilizes the PSA. We kind of have a clue that it’s doing what it’s supposed to. But to give it a fair trial, typically six to twelve weeks is required on any new medication I would say. Patient: Do you think that in the meantime the cancer will increase? Doctor: It seems very unlikely to me. Okay. Mainly because your scans haven’t changed. If they had… Patient: Except for the brightness. Doctor: Except for the brightness, yeah. If they had changed, you know if you had three new spots now, we would probably be having a different discussion. We’d say well I think we need to – got to go to chemotherapy or something that will work quickly or maybe Lynparza give that a try. But I think we have room to wait and see if we can squeeze any effect from the Xtandi if that is the resistance pathway that your cancer is stuck at which… Family Member: Mm Hmm.

Patient: Right. Doctor: This tells you, you know, you can read the consent. We’ll review your records to see if you’re eligible. Otherwise, we can start the chemo in a few weeks. Stop the abiraterone now. Continue on the prednisone. It says stop the abiraterone, and it tells you on this page that I refilled your ibuprofen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then it says that, huh, I refilled your ibuprofen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: All right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: All righty. Thanks doc. Doctor: You hang in there. Hope we get you out of pain soon. Patient: Can I ask you a question? Doctor: Uh-huh.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: So I think that’s what we were you know were tentatively sort of earmarking for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, both _____ or myself, I think you as well agree - Patient: Yes. Doctor: Did I put words in your mouth? Patient: Nope. Doctor: That’s how you feel? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, so then let’s stay the course. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then I will have ___ follow up with you for next month or I’ll just get the picture be out soon. Patient: Okay. And the Xtandi is, I’m out of refills. So I don’t know if C or you? It was prescribed by her. I forgot to mention to her last time because I

Patient: Good. Doctor: - but because they’re filming – Patient: Now. Doctor: - uh they wanted to see me with you – Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Yeah (Chuckles) Doctor: So he’s still very much a part of the team. Patient: Good. Family Member: We like him very much. (Chuckles) Doctor: Okay, anything else? Patient: That’s it. Family Member: That’s it. Doctor: Let me see what we have in here in terms of just follow-up. So he’s already set up for his shot.

Patient: Okay. Family Member: It’s almost every three weeks. Patient: Yeah. I don’t know if, yeah, if we screw up. Family Member: These are all the dates on all the different things he has to work through for cataract surgery. Doctor: Yeah. These are just the follow-ups. One week, one day, two weeks, and four weeks. Okay. That’s not a big deal. All uh. And those days are changeable. I mean, we can do Monday versus another. Family Member: Sure. Um hum. We can put off the cataract surgery, too. Doctor: Yeah. If he had to. Family Member: But it’s hard to get. Doctor: But for now let’s keep it. Family Member: That’s what I think. We’ve waited a long time. Doctor: Don’t, don’t change anything until we see what the dates fall out to be. Family Member: Fine. Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.10 years ago or more: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::10 years ago or more

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind::: strongly disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Prefer to self-describe (please specify): What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Prefer to self-describe (please specify)

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do you see him or is he on tour? Patient: I saw, no, you know, he’s having some uh medical problems Doctor: Oh, no. Patient: Are we in the cone of silence here? Doctor: Well, you’re on. Hey. Could you guys, can you guys put down the thingy? The, the cut this part out? Patient: Uh, I can tell you, I can tell you when we’re walking out. Healthcare Professional: They are moving. Doctor: Yes. Healthcare Professional: That one moved that way. Doctor: So just uh can you put us on mute a minute? Thank you. Patient: Pardon? Doctor: Does your ex know?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You have Provenge. Um, so um, the one standard thing that’s left is a radiation-based thing but that’s really only for disease of the bone. You have lymph node as well. So I would sort of not use that. The other thing that’s left is chemotherapy, flavors, uh so that’s something we could always go to. The other sort of unfortunately gray zone (beeping) Patient: Sure. Doctor: Uh and some of that’s clinical trial. A lot of the clinical trials we have right now are hormonal based. So it’s Zytiga plus something, Xtandi plus something. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Versus something. So unfortunately uh you wouldn’t fit all those trials because of the prior treatments we have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we also have some chemotherapy trials which we potentially could consider if we were ready to do chemotherapy. Um, the um, trial, the trial in the cracks that we have, one is an immune therapy trial. Uh so right now when we get immune therapy, the reason that we use it for a lot of cancers, they haven’t worked so well by itself for prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So one thing we can look at is what if we give two immune therapies versus one. In an earlier study we did we saw more men that it worked in more men. So now we’re doing a bigger study. The down side of that is when we give two immune therapies the toxicity is much worse. So about half of the men I, I would estimate headed to the hospital with toxicity. Patient: Oh, really? Doctor: The main toxicity is really bad diarrhea. Because what these immune therapies are doing is sort of tipping the balance a little bit, trying to get the immune system to start seeing the cancer as foreign.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then uh we will get back in touch with you either later this week- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Or early next week. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And uh- Patient: About this? Doctor: About this and also about the Xtandi itself. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Because the the Xtandi will be a part of the treatment anyways. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um so I’m I’m going to go ahead and try to get that one authorized in the meantime.
